title: When will it be announced that the Kaesong Industrial Complex is reopening?
preds:
During last month's talks, the first in more than a decade, the two sides agreed to completely restore their military communication lines.
http://english.yonhapnews.co.kr/national/2018/07/31/0301000000AEN20180731001600315.html
Clock is almost out on this one.

North Korea missed the boat as most of the Kaesong companies have gone elsewhere for cheap labor. Dateline 7-24-2018 About 30 ex-Kaesong firms move overseas for cheap labor
  -- http://english.yonhapnews.co.kr/search1/2603000000.html
The North has to show some movement tward denuclearization. And the South should give an olive branch.

They are working on it, but not much time before this question closes. Dateline  7-19-2018  South Korean officials and workers are conducting repair work at the Gaeseong Industrial Complex in North Korea in a bid to open an inter-Korean liaison office there in August.  A Unification Ministry official in Seoul told reporters on Thursday that some of the South Korean group began staying in living quarters set up within the complex earlier this week to carry out the repair work, while others are commuting from home.  Since repair efforts began July second, all of the workers had commuted on a daily basis by crossing the Military Demarcation Line. The facilities in Gaeseong have not been used since South Korea pulled out from the joint industrial complex in February 2016, in the wake of the North's nuclear and missile provocations. The decision to open a liaison office inside Gaeseong was reached at the April 27th summit between South Korean President Moon Jae-in and North Korean leader Kim Jong-un. -- http://world.kbs.co.kr/service/news_view.htm?lang=e&Seq_Code=137941&__s=rvbgnjhe3nqq4qfatdac&utm_source=drip&utm_medium
While recent diplomatic events are proving positive, it is not sufficient to make the progress required.
Counterbalancing past prediction. Felt too strongly about Kaesong opening early

http://ajudaily.com/view/20180621180839468 SEOUL -- The reopening of a joint inter-Korean industrial zone just north of the heavily armed border depends on progress in North Korea's denuclearization, a senior South Korean official said Thursday (6/21), citing U.S.-led international sanctions. Vice Unification Minister Chun Hae-sung told a forum in Seoul Thursday that South Korea would consider lifting a cross-border trade ban only after the international community sees "visible" progress in denuclearization. "I think we may have to review it after the conditions are set," he said. "Talks on lifting sanctions are possible after we see visible measures in denuclearization."
. . . 
South Korean President Moon Jae-in promised to reopen the complex if North Korea returned to the dialogue table, but Seoul is cautious as it depends on how Pyongyang will implement agreements. The two Koreas agreed to set up a liaison office for cross-border exchanges and cooperation under a landmark peace declaration signed by the leaders of the two Koreas at their summit in April. Renovation has been underway this week at an office building in Kaesong to house the liaison office. The South's Unification Ministry in charge of cross-border affairs hopes to open the liaison office in August.

Things have been happening pretty quickly after the meeting between Trump and Kim Jong Un in addition to the multiple meetings Kim has had with China and South Korea. I believe the momentum will continue between North and South since as of late, a reunion is being planned between family members from the two Koreas.

http://www.arirang.co.kr/news/News_View.asp?nseq=219060 " . . . very week, business owners hold special task force meetings to prepare for a possible reopening of the industrial park.  They meet so often as reopening Kaesong would be an extremely complicated process. It's not just UN sanctions. The factories and equipment would need repairing and who pays for that remains unclear. There's the issue of deferred wages to around 50-thousand North Korean workers. More than 100 South Korean companies received government insurance payouts following the shutdown, should they return it to the government when re-entering the complex all these legal issues would have to be sorted out."  Regardless, a survey by the Korean Federation of SMEs shows over 90 percent of South Korean companies would be willing to go back to the Kaesong Industrial Complex if it opens again, citing cheap labor, high productivity and its geographical location.  "For twelve years, the Kaesong Industrial Complex served as a symbol of peace between the two Koreas. We have survived the last two years and now that the government is planning to set up a joint liaison office, we believe thatfinallythe complex will be able to resume operations in the near future."
~~~~~~~
COMMENT:  This question requires only an announcement of opening (a low bar).  The DJT administration has shown itself capable of reversing direction overnight, so the lifting of sanctions might be quickly achieved if DJT wanted it.   Also, the Pres of RSK is every eager to improve relations with DPRK, so might press for an announcement of plans to reopen to create pressure to lift the sanctions.
Planning fallacy is always a factor. Less will be done per unit time than you think. Even with the good DPRK warm up of relations, it is less than a 1 in 10 chance.

My guess (no evidence so I will not call it a forecast) is that in the next two or three months the Trump/Kim talks will not produce an agreement of any substance - the US will not agree to give up its nuclear weapons and allow inspectors from NK full access to US sites to verify that the US has permanently given up its nuclear weapons, so NK will also decline to do so. Therefore a lessor agreement will be made where promises are made but no verification will take place (no need for verification; when two gentlemen such as Trump and Kim give their word only a cynic would doubt it). Both parties will declare "peace in our time" (that sounds familiar? Has it been said before?) put in for the Nobel Peace Prize and Russia and China will resume trading with NK. The US might not because some grumpy people in Congress might for political reasons question if a substantive solution to the NK nuclear problem was been reached, but that's fine, NK would be able to trade with Russia and China. The KIC will reopen, but probably not for six months or so. End of story (until next time)

Joining the crowd. It's gonna hurt when this gets added to my score...
Reason I'm changing is nothing happened in the wake of either the ROK-DPRK or the USA-DPRK summits.

According to a report from South Korea's Yonhap News Agency, the chairman of the Kaesong Industrial Complex Enterprise Association applied for permission to visit the complex to conduct preliminary inspections of South Korean-owned facilities back on February 26, but the South Korean government has yet to respond to the request. Said the chairman: "We are all set to make the trip north. Once the government gives permission, we can get up there within a day." Conducting these facilities inspections would be the first step towards reopening the complex. The association believes the government will grant such permission by the end of this month or next month and that the park will be operational again "within the year." Regarding the economic will to reopen the complex, the article notes that in a survey of 105 of the companies that had factories in Kaesong, 95% said they were willing to return.  http://m.news.naver.com/read.nhn?mode=LSD&mid=sec&sid1=101&oid=001&aid=0010145736
They've opened a liaison office there, which probably means reopening the complex fairly soon.  Probably not in time for this deadline, though.

I don't see much for Kim and Trump to put their teeth into in the way of an agreement moving forward so I expect this to be among the choices of "things to show his base" for Trump, even if it doesn't make sense analytically. A lot of our analysis seems to be still stuck in the old politics mentality that lead to predictions like Trump won't win, a US pres won't meet with NK leader because it legitimizes them, John Bolton's appt will prevent any meeting from happening etc etc.

DT's NKorean initiative have undermined the  pressure the west had placed on the NKorean regime.  Link below covers changes in SKorea, China, that will undermine any attempt to further isolate NK.
From the below link: "“Trump’s campaign is over,” said Kim Hyun-wook, a professor at the Korea National Diplomatic Academy. “The diplomatic openings with North Korea have already been taking a toll on the maximum pressure campaign.”
....
Preparations are already underway in China, South Korea and Russia, which share land borders with North Korea, for better ties with the isolated nation. Officials from South Korea visited a shuttered joint economic project in Kaesong, North Korea, on Friday, part of a government effort to prepare for a possible easing of sanctions.
.....
Russia has long been skeptical of the sanctions regime, and South Korea’s Moon has proposed a three-way study on potential joint projects, including railways, gas and power linking Siberia to the Korean peninsula. “Even if the summit fails and U.S.-North Korea tensions resurface, Russia is unlikely to support new rounds of sanctions on North Korea,” said Artyom Lukin, a professor at Far Eastern Federal University 
...
“If previously adopted U.N. sanctions continue to be in effect, Russia will abide by them, but it will probably find some legal ways and loopholes to make their enforcement as mild as possible.” Kim has met Chinese President Xi Jinping two times in recent months and analysts say Beijing’s willingness to maintain last year’s level of pressure on North Korea is waning.
https://www.reuters.com/article/us-northkorea-usa-maximumpressure-insigh/door-already-ajar-trump-may-struggle-to-isolate-north-korea-again-idUSKCN1J600L
Affirming for now but will reassess after 12 June summit
While unlikely, it's still possible that such an announcement could be made as part of the current talks.

http://koreajoongangdaily.joins.com/news/article/article.aspx?aid=3048842 "High-level delegations from both sides held their first meeting since the recent summits between South Korean President Moon Jae-in and North Korean leader Kim Jong-un. On the agenda was implementation of a declaration signed by the two leaders during their historic summit on April 27. “The South and North agreed to open a joint liaison office inside the Kaesong Industrial Complex, where officials from both countries will be stationed, to guarantee inter-Korean cooperation,” the two delegations said in a joint statement on Friday. “We also agreed to continue cooperating via written communication on how best to celebrate the 18th anniversary of the June 15 declaration.”
. . .
The two delegations also agreed to hold additional inter-Korean meetings at the border village of Panmunjom, including one on military cooperation on June 14 and another on sports on June 18, where they expect to discuss an inter-Korean basketball game and fielding joint teams for the Asian Games in August. They will also hold a meeting on family reunions at Mount Kumgang in the North on June 22.
~~~~~~~
COMMENT:  With all these meetings being held and plans for additional meetings being made, I think that the chances for an announcement of the reopening of KIC have increased.  The sticking point may be UN sanctions against cooperation with DPRK; they probably will need to be lifted.
Will be really annoying if Moon & Kim announce this in the next month.
If the Peninsulads continue to get along so famously, this would be a logical step.  Coming up a bit; probably regret it later.
with this bizaro Trump negotiations, maybe it gets announced because something needs to be announced, even though actually reo [ening isn't feasible
No signs either party is interested in something like this for now.
Adjusting for passage of time & moving closer to consensus. Still more bullish than the crowd

No chance now give they haven't learned there lesson and continue to be so arrogant and aggressive. The chutzpah of these delusional nutters. It's mind boggling. Just bomb them already. Sick of it, let's move on and deal with China not playing by the rules. Stain on civilisation and humanity I say.  I'll sign up.   WoC only 90%? 1428 bets from 450 bettors.
with delays in the Trump - Un meeting, do not see progress on issues like Kaesong
Staying put despite the consensus & great research of ithers
I thought this would be an easy gesture at their next summit given improving relations but now the summit is postponed indefinitely so back to no.
Should the Trump-Kim meeting be a success, reopening the complex will take time. Announcements might be made before August 1st however.

I know Trump says a lot of things... Smart! Sad! But I think something USA, China, and South Korea can agree on is the need to stabilise North Korea economically. Trump said he wants to get them to same prosperity as South. Regardless of how viable that is, having increased production and trade will help lift out of poverty (like Chinese economic miracle). All they have to do is make an announcement... Besides North Koreans have already sold everything not bolted down in Kaesong (received in Chinese markets).
If even a portion of what Kim Fatty III is proposing is true and speed of events continues, believe an announcement before end of July is possible. It can’t be all one-sided - need to toss NK a bone. Maybe “this time” will be different from prior thaws?
caving to crowd wisdom - I’ve been too optimistic and expect Americans/Chinese to draw this out.

This will be an obvious political move for both sides and the facility will be reopened.
The only reason to not open it would be a draconian move by Trumpy of some sort.
Even if opened its long-term viability will be of low probability because of the distance between North and South Korean politics.

I am assuming that "an announcement that KIC is opening" is going to be scored differently from "an announcement that KIC will be opening if......".
So on that basis I doubt that SK will agree to it being opened before NK has done something specific as part of a wider deal. So it would think "will be opening if...." has a 50% chance, but "is opening" looks unlikely.

https://www.nknews.org/2018/05/seoul-carrying-out-preparations-to-finance-inter-korean-projects-minister/ Minister of Unification Cho Myoung-gyon said that plans for an inter-Korean liaison office in the DPRK city of Kaesong would not result in the reopening of the now-shuttered Kaesong Industrial Complex (KIC). “Even though the South-North Korea joint liaison office is established in Kaesong area, I’d like to say it is separate from the resumption of the Kaesong Industrial Complex,” Cho said. The KIC, which is believed to now be being operated by the North Koreans, was unilaterally closed by the Park Geun-hye administration in 2015. Long a rare symbol of inter-Korean economic cooperation, current President Moon Jae-in while on the campaign trail promised to reopen and expand the complex: a move which would, many argue, represent a violation of international sanctions prohibiting money transfers to the North. So, too, would many of Seoul’s plans for inter-Korean economic cooperation – and any projects would likely require some kind of liberalization of international sanctions before they could be given the green light. And while a planned meeting between North Korean leader Kim Jong Un and U.S. President Donald Trump has led some to suggest sanctions relief may emerge in the future, one White House official this week ruled out any such early concessions. Speaking to Fox News on Sunday, recently appointed National Security Advisor John Bolton said any relief of sanctions would require a full commitment by the North to denuclearization.

http://english.chosun.com/site/data/html_dir/2018/04/30/2018043001252.html In the survey of 101 businesses that operated at Kaesong late last month, 27 said they would return as soon as the industrial park reopens, while 70 wanted to wait to gauge the new circumstances. Only four said they will never go back.
. . . 
Almost all or 98 predicted that it will reopen during President Moon Jae-in's term in office. But they were unsure of the exact time, with 39 saying some time this year, 20 next year and 40 in 2020-2022.
. . . 
When he was running for president, Moon pledged to reopen the complex, but the issue was not discussed during last week's inter-Korean summit as strict international sanctions remain in place. 
~~~~~~~
COMMENT:  I think that the international sanctions are the big stumbling block right now.  After DJT & KJU meet, perhaps those sanctions will be lifted.  Then I assume there'll be an announcement of Kaesong re-opening.

http://koreajoongangdaily.joins.com/news/article/article.aspx?aid=3047464 Kaesong firms hopeful complex might reopen Apr 27,2018. . . .“We have been waiting for this moment for more than two years,” said Shin Han-yong, chairman of the Corporate Association of Kaesong Industrial Complex, on Thursday. “We see hope and although we don’t expect an immediate result, we are optimistic that the industrial complex will gradually reopen.” The road to reopening the complex won’t be easy, as it would need the cooperation of the United Nations and the U.S. to lift a number of sanctions. “An agreement between the two Koreas wouldn’t mean anything until the U.S. and the global community eases up on the sanctions,” Shin said. 
. . . 
There are 124 South Korean companies operating in the industrial complex when it was closed by President Park Geun-hye in February 2016. 
. . . 
“According to reports provided by the United Nations, North Korea’s real GDP as of 2016 was $14.9 billion, which is equivalent to 1.15 percent of South Korea’s,” said Oh Tae-dong, an analyst at NH Investment & Securities. “[Investors] have to take into account the actual benefits that South Korean companies might get with the growth of North Korea’s economy.”  In fact, only 26 percent of companies said they would return to the complex if it reopens, while the majority of companies said they would wait until the South Korean government introduces a law to protect their businesses.
~~~~~~
COMMENT:  The UN sanctions are a serious obstacle and the fact that only 26% of the companies want to return suggests to me that there isn't a ton of pressure and that there will be a lot of hoops and red-tape to work through beforehand.  Changing forecast to 98% not before 8/1.

Peace treaty! @praedico makes a good point that while UN sanctions may need to be lifted, an announcement is all that is necessary. North Korea has been making improvements on Kaesong since last fall, so there is no hesitation on their side.

The closing of Kaesong was done illegally by Pres Pak, who has since been convicted of crimes and sentenced to jail, AND since then sanctions have been imposed on DPRK that will make it difficult for Kaesong to be re-opened.  I had hopes that the re-opening of Kaesong would have been on the agenda of the KJU-Moon summit or brought up between them, but I find no evidence that it was.
Had been waiting to see how the NK and SK meetings resolved. I think it is more clear now and I don't see this happening until further agreements are defined and sanctions are eased or lifted.

It looks possible that some deal with NK will be made following meetings between NK and SK, and NK and USA. It is reported that the NK nuclear test site was destroyed by the last nuclear test (and subsequent seismic activity) - this was initially reported some months ago, but there seems to be confirmation. So presumably NK will not be able to conduct nuclear tests for some time, which made it easy for NK to agree to close the test site. That clearly does not mean that NK will agree to give up its nuclear program, but it makes it easier for NK to say it has stopped development. If Trump wants to show he has won a victory over NK, both Trump and NK could claim they had reached a deal where by NK stops nuclear work and the US removes some sanctions, and if Trump says he trusts Kim (which he more or less has already said) it could agreed that NK does not need to agree to very comprehensive nuclear inspections. (A "don't look to hard" so we can say "we see no evidence", while NK can carry on in secret, kind of deal.)   So the first steps toward reopening KIC could be started before 1st Aug e.g. reopening will open if certain things take place first, but I suspect a full announcement will come after that date.
High on list of DPRK for talks

They (Moon and Kim Fatty III) are supposed to meet Apr 27 - 2 days. Am high at 1/10 chance of announcing re-opening. Announcing only - likely date of actual opening months out and after other hurdles/meetings. South closed this due to missile and nuke programs. Fatty needs a bone - he appears to have done much on diplomatic front without actually risking much (yet). He has played his hand well and will be looking for quid pro quo. 
Supposedly talks are focused on peace treaty and some sort of normalization but economics should also be in play.

I'm not sure that South Korea is free to reopen the Kaesong Industrial Complex until the UN lifts sanctions: http://www.scmp.com/news/asia/article/2143005/why-economic-cooperation-could-be-stumbling-block-inter-korea-summit But it may be free to announce. That would surprise me.
NK makes $ from it & Moon is pro-anything towards reconciliation.

Assuming summit preparations go forward, Kaesong is an easy thing to put in the package.   It's actually not much of a concession since both NK and SK want it.  If the summit package also includes a formal end to the Korean War (possible), a pathway toward normalized NK-SK-USA relations (possible), and some hope for eventual de-nuclearization of the Korean peninsula (more difficult, but possible with fuzzy language), everyone might sign off.   The personalities are volatile of course, so I'm out on a limb here.  The whole thing could fizzle and pop.  But the narcissistic egos of Trump and Kim may just fancy the the idea of trotting off to Stockholm, hand-in-hand, to pick up the Nobel Peace Prize.
Increasingly but waiting to see what happens after the 4.27 meeting between KJU and MJI at the DMZ peace house.
Things seem to be moving fast.

assuming the meeting of NK and SK shall take place in 6 days, as to the customs some „gifts“ have to be exchanged.....
so why not discussing the reopening of this KIC at an earlier than predicted date?
everything else has been pre-announced ahead of April 27

27 Apr Inter Korean Summit is aiming high. High hopes that the summit will announce end of war making current truce a peace treaty. Doubling my odds of the current window up to 24% and doubling odds of May - July up to 56%. Taking it all out of the final time period's 'hide.'
as @WBHumanoid has pointed out, what better time to make such an announcement than April 27th!
what better time to announce than April 27?
April 27th is just cutting it a bit close though. Maybe it'll happen after the Kim-Trumpy Show in late May-early June.

Dateline 4-17-2018 Visitors to North Korea to be barred from Kaesong and DMZ next week.
Heavy roadworks and rehabilitation also reported on Kaesong-Pyongyang highway. -- https://www.nknews.org/2018/04/visitors-to-north-korea-to-be-barred-from-kaesong-and-dmz-next-week/
The Moon-Kim summit happens before 30APR18. There is a remote 2% chance something weird goes down and their is an announcement to reopen.

Something might (but probably won't) come from the meetings the new friendly Mr Kim has planned in the next couple of months. 
My guess is that Kim is just buying time to get his next demo of his weapon system ready. My guess is he thinks he will have is weapons development back to business as usual by June.
I really see the 27 April Summit as an opportunity to announce this, but I don't have any evidence to boost the percentage. Standing pat for now.
There is some chance that an announcement could come after the upcoming summit (which as of this writing appears to still be on).
Shifting a few points because I can see this coming out of the upcoming inter-Korean summit.
An announcement would occur after the Moon Jae-in/Kim Jung-un meeting. I predict sooner than later. There is a chance that the reopening could be part of the end-of-month meeting.
I think they'll save this as a garnish around the de-Nuke talks.

1-99 to 3-97 due to summit. What revenues did it have before? $20mn? $100mn? Edit: bigger biccies then. 
"The South Korean unification minister, Hong Yong-pyo, said North Korea had earned 616 billion won (£355m) in cash from Kaesong, which relies on South Korean investment and technology, and tens of thousands of skilled North Korean workers."  “It appears that such funds have not been used to pave the way to peace, as the international community had hoped, but rather to upgrade its nuclear weapons and long-range missiles,” Hong told reporters in Seoul.  "Last year, 124 South Korean companies hired 54,000 North Korean workers to produce socks, wristwatches and other goods worth about £340m."  $476,000,000 USD is nothing to sneeze at. Could (did) pay for a few months missiley stuff in famished East China, I mean North Korea.

I'm holding steady on 0/0/0/8/92. I don't see Kaesong being discussed without denuclearization and the UN sanctions being removed. But there could be a path outlined for both and this path would be announced and trigger the question.

Had I made this forecast six months ago, when armed conflict seemed more likely, the numbers would be completely different. But NK seems to be on a charm offensive with overtures to SK, China and the US. Perhaps the sanctions and Trump's bluster are having an effect; perhaps as well NK's economy is worse off than we think (which would be pretty bad).

With the developing momentum for a major Summit, this issue will probably be put on the back burner. Additionally International sanctions would be too problematic to realistically discuss investment and reopening of the complex. The issue of Kaesong is now a third or fourth tier priority and will only reopen when several major issues are resolved sanctions being the first and foremost. Much negotiation has to take place before the sanctions allow investment in North Korea.

Outside view: 50%
- This level of announcement should be expected at a summit between Moon and Kim, so this devolves to probability of such a summit in various periods.  Pace has picked up and a summit by 31 July is moderately likely.  Anouncement is another matter (see Inside view).
Inside view, only 23.3% for before 1 August 2018:
- Probably U.S. is leaning on RoK to withheld this announcement until after Trump--Kim summit. 0%
- RoK can use this announcement as leverage to get itself invited to any Trump--Kim summit. 20%
- DPK almost certainly prefers to meet with Moon before and separately from Trump and to get this announcement then, but their power to get this is mainly persuasive, so 100% but half-weight.

I think there is increasing likelihood that this could be announced as part of direct ROK-DPRK talks in Apr in run up to supposed talks between US & DPRK in May. Easy low hanging fruit for ROK to show progress and it would be a good income move for DPRK that helps it bypass tough US sanctions.
Per @iroquis77... agree appointment of “madder dawg” Bolton is going to change relations with North Korea, Iran, Russia, and China. Even Republicans didn’t want him in place...
As the two Korean gentlemen get together, this would be an easily implemented and fairly inexpensive bit of glitter to show for the meeting.

The facility will not be reopened until sanctions are lifted, which will not occur without serious negotiations about North Korea's nuclear program.  They will not negotiate seriously until a treaty is effected ending the hostilities of the police action known as the Korean War.  China and South Korea would each approve of that peace.  The US has historically been the objector.

Although the upcoming Korean summit in April may list Kaesong as an agenda item, unlikely much will come of it (acknowledge Moon's intent, as noted in the question). Since the shut down in February 2016 was a directed response to Pyongyang's fourth nuclear test and long-range rocket launch, any announcement of the complex being considered for a re-opening will most likely likely be based on Seoul's satisfaction with DPRK's demonstrated progress toward denuclearization.
Downgraded to 8, as Kaesong will be subject to UN sanctions that must be lifted.  The added bureaucratic layer will delay announcement.
Kaesong will likely be on the agenda at the Inter-Korea Summit in April 2018.
Kaesong will very likely be on the agenda at the Korean Summit talks.  Announcements will likely follow.

Rationally NK would need to give something before SK (with the OK from the US) agreed to reopen KIC, but these are not necessarily rational times, so someone might agree to this. They could always announce (on Twitter of course) that KIC will reopen after NK does some specific thing.  
Of course NK could have restarted its tests before then.
looks like everyone's trying to strike while the iron's hot.  expect more good cop v. bad cop statements from NK and Trump-Moon
Wouldn’t be entirely surprising if the resulted from Kim & Moon’s meeting in April
Everything on hold until two Presidents meet.
Nothing will happen before the historic meeting between the USA and DPRK.  South Korea will be at the table, so Kaesong will be on the table.

Moon in April
Trump in May
With direct talks expected between POTUS & KJU in May, there will be intense pressure on both sides to produce some semblance of tangible results. This seems like low hanging fruit to me.

KIC was closed due to a (presumed) veiled ICBM test launch in early 2016 which followed a nearly two year hiatus in missile tests. Since 2016, engine and missile tests have been so regular that we're currently in the second longest "quiet period" (3 months and 1 week). Despite the superficial show of solidarity at the Olympics, no announcement will be made until we go at least 6 months to 1 year between any tests. [Revised previous prediction based on recent developments: https://www.wsj.com/articles/kim-jong-un-invites-trump-to-meet-in-north-korea-1520555014 ]
Suspect this has to wait further progress on the nuclear and security issues.
This will not happen before UN sanctions are lifted.  The north would have to give up its nukes and completely change before that will happen.
Due diligence and the whole process will take longer with delays on both sides.
Many obstacles to reopening will delay it.
Post Olympics bump or it’s not going to happen

There is a small possibility that the increased sense of optimism and cooperation fostered by the Pyeongchang Olympics will lead to the reopening of the KIC. Since South Korea closed the KIC in response to North Korea's growing nuclear ambitions, however, it is unlikely that the KIC will reopen unless nuclear-related discussions make some serious headway in the near future.

The North Koreans are using ICBMs to leverage the South Koreans to offer financial incentives.  One of these would be the industrial complex in the DMZ area.  Such financial incentives would carve out an glimmer of hope during the rapid ratcheting up of sanctions by the United States (and China) on North Korea.  Further "internal" negotiations for DMZ activities increases the possibility of Seoul using this industrial zone to expand Panmunjom talks in the DMZ area.

North Korea appears to have no intentions to denuclearize the country nor do they have any intent on stopping the progression of their nuclear program.  The complex was closed down in 2016 after North Korea conducted its fourth nuclear test.  Since the closure, North Korea has conducted two more nuclear tests.  Another factor that would now make it difficult to reopen the complex would be the fact that a U.N. sanctions related review would be needed.  When the complex was open South Korea firms would send the wages to a committee running the complex who would then distribute coupons or bills to the workers which was equal to 30-40 percent of the total wages.  The sanctions placed on North Korea by the UN has called for closing such committees that were used to distribute the wages.  Therefore, in order for the same process to be utilized if the complex were to re-open the UN would have to review their sanctions or eliminate these sanctions.  
http://english.yonhapnews.co.kr/northkorea/2017/05/11/80/0401000000AEN20170511006000315F.html
If this happens it will be an attempt to stave off an armed conflict with the US.
North and South must meet either during or shortly after the Olympics. After that, reopening the facility will be in short order.

a) While South Korean investors in the Kaesong complex are currently lobbying the Ministry of Reunification, aiming for the period between the Olympic and Paralympic games (https://www.csmonitor.com/World/Asia-Pacific/2018/0208/South-Korean-firms-hope-North-South-complex-will-reopen), 
b) the original reason for shutting down the Kaesong Complex (DPRK evasion of sanctions) is unlikely to have changed in the last years, especially following FinCEN's Advisory on DPRK Sanction Evasions (https://www.fincen.gov/sites/default/files/advisory/2017-11-02/DPRK%20Financing%20Advisory%20FINAL%2011022017_0.pdf) and the accusation of Korean banks in assisting Iran and DPRK to evade sanctions (e.g. Shinhan Bank & IBK)

'We need to go back': South Korean firms dream of returning North
An official from South Korea’s Unification Ministry told Reuters that now was not the time to discuss reopening Kaesong and that talks could only begin when “the North Korean nuclear issue has to some extent entered a phase of a resolution”. For Shin, that stance means that improved relations between North Korea and the United States would also be critical. “We cautiously expect it may be possible to reopen the factory within this year, should the Olympics lead to the improvement of relations between two Koreas and between North Korea and U.S.,” he said.

Up until now, I considered this question to be a total lock on "not before August 2018." The new NK strategy is seems to be to love bomb SK in hopes of opening a gap between SK and the United States.  The Kaesong Industrial Complex is the big chip in this game.  Restarting Kaesong would throw cash at NK and subvert the UN Sanctions regime,  Yet it's not out of the question that SK leadership might go wobbly on this at some point.  SK stepped out of line late last year with an initial refusal not to allow deployment of THAAD.  Eventually they caved and went along with the US.  They still live in hope that appeasement can work.  Nothing will happen until the Olympics are over.  At that point, NK will put Kaesong back on the table and it could become part of some future grand bargain between NK and SK, that might or might not include the US.   Chances are still fairly good this question will time out.   Despite what it says in the SUPERFORECASTING book, I don't agree with the marshmallow strategy of being a hedger.  I always feel bad about doing it.

The DPRK said the two sides should have more contact and focus on improving their bilateral relationship first before discussing arrangements for reuniting families split by the 1950-1953 Korean War, the spokesman said, citing sources from Panmunjom. Family reunion is one of the major agendas for the inter-Korean talks. The last family reunion was held in October 2015. About 100 people from each side, selected randomly by computer, had a brief meeting at the Mount Kumgang resort in the DPRK.

In December 2017, an expert panel investigating the decision to close the park found that there was no evidence that North Korea had diverted wages to fund its nuclear program. The head of the panel Kim Jong-soo said, "The presidential office inserted the wage-diversion argument as major grounds, yet without concrete information, sufficient evidence and consultations with related agencies, mainly citing defector testimonies that lack objectivity and credibility. This impairs the decision’s legitimacy and could constrain our ground over a future restart of the complex, while hampering the companies’ rights to protect their assets due to the hasty pullout process." A group of businesses who suffered losses of 250 billion won ($200 million) due to the closure demanded an apology and said, "Now that the wage-diversion claim has proved groundless, the government must apologize for abusing state power to suspend the complex and make utmost efforts to reopen it.

Based on the clarification that a "Unilateral re-opening will not suffice" there is very little hope for the KIC.   Here are a few reasons: 
1)  North Korea has re-opened the center on its own:  Thus would gain very little from allowing the south access.
2)  A Joint opening of the complex is a violation of current UN Sanctions:  As such, a review would be necessary, and then an exemption would need to be drafted, and approved.
3) North opened a hydroelectric plant to power the complex.  This is crucial because South's leverage over the area was originally that it supplied the power / infrastructure to the zone. 
4) The Complex is Inside North Korea:  Thus, they can legally confiscate and utilize the facility even though it's production was largely financed by the South. 
5) Business Alternatives:  There were more than 100 companies operating in the facility at the time of it's closure.  With more than a year having passed, these companies have had time / and needed to transition to a more sustainable production alternative.  I suspect that this will no longer be considered a joint venture, but rather become known as a North Korean industrial complex in the near future.

North Korea appears to be conducting agricultural activity amid the (shuttered?) industrial facilities there. Does this activity account for the totality of what is going on there? Or is it possible that reports of activity there include attempts, successful or not, to restart these industrial facilities? If evidence were to surface that North Korea has figured out how to operate those facilities, then it would only need South Korea assistance in order to evade sanctions against its exports. That would lower probability. If North Korea can't operate these facilities alone, then there remain two hurdles instead of just the sanctions evasion hurdle. I'm not going to 100% not before Aug. 1, 2018 because it is possible that the standoff over nuclear threats might ease by then. In that case, reopening the joint North/South facilities could be a welcome economic boost. Dateline 10-26-2017 More activity underway at Kaesong Industrial Complex. satellite imagery suggests.... Possible agricultural activity observed in several areas of shuttered KIC --  NK News [news@nknews.org]

facts in @Anneinak 's (always awesome) research seem to evince some real desire to reopen the Kaesong industrial complex. North Korea needs to turn a corner diplomatically; if they do, I believe they'll start to get buy-in from the US and South Korea. but that "if" is a wildcard. I've been very bad at predicting what North Korea will do, even though its policy objectives strike me as pretty clear. North Korea's policy objectives seem to be: keep the Kim dynasty in power & get the ability to launch/aim/detonate a nuclear warhead. (I'm not aware of any other high priority North Korean policy goals, and options for having policy goals internationally are largely limited by sanctions that are the price for its taking steps toward nuclear capability.) At this point, it seems to me that any progress toward the nuclear-capability policy goal is inconsistent with this question resolving in the affirmative; I haven't seen signs from North Korea that it will relent on that goal (though China's supposed buy-in on sanctions is often cited as evidence the U.S. is making diplomatic progress on the North Korea issue generally... didn't those ICBM launcher trucks come from China as mining equipment that was later modified?).

I assume that both North and South Korea would have to announce a reopening to resolve the question. Accusations that North Korea has unilaterally reopened some factories came from a US-funded radio network: http://english.hani.co.kr/arti/english_edition/e_northkorea/814255.html Of course, South Korea unilaterally closed it, so the North's move is hardly surprising. South Korea Pres. Moon Jae-in wants to reopen it, unlike his predecessor, but the current posturing competition between US and North Korea as well an North Korea's recent missile tests have made this agenda difficult for him. @Anneinak has asked for clarification. I will sit at consensus until we get some guidance. But, if the unilateral reopening by North Korea (if true and substantiated) counts, then it has already happened. I don't think there has been an announcement though.

https://www.voanews.com/a/south-korea-company-owners-protest-kaesong/4067104.html "South Korean companies that were forced to shut down operations in the Kaesong Industrial Complex in North Korea in 2016 have petitioned the government in Seoul to investigate reports that Pyongyang has reopened the facility without their consent. The North/South joint venture with South Korea was suspended last year to punish the Kim Jong Un government for conducting nuclear and missile tests, and to cut off a possible source of funding for Pyongyang’s illicit weapons development program. "The South Korean Unification Ministry could not confirm that the complex has been reopened, but did say that recent bus movements and illuminated street lamps in the site have been observed. "The Corporate Association of Kaesong Industrial Complex that represents the 123 South Korean manufacturing companies that operated factories in the North Korean facility said Thursday it wants to send a delegation to inspect their property. “It is our asset, which we invested in according to North Korean law, and procedures set by both governments of the two Koreas. So as owners with rights to the assets, it is necessary for us to check the situation and status of our assets and find out whether the complex is really being operated or not,” said Kim Seo-jin, with the Kaesong Industrial Complex Association. . . . "To make the complex fully operational again, North Korea would also be hard pressed to replace the electricity supply that came from South Korea, according to the Kaesong business owners. . . .  "Pyongyang responded to Seoul’s decision in 2016 to suspend Kaesong operations by imposing military control over the site, freezing all assets of the Kaesong companies, and deporting the remaining South Korean managers and staff still there. . . .  "The Kaesong association estimated its members left behind over $600 million in equipment and raw materials, and many of the Kaesong companies have been unable to recover . . .  “That's one of reasons why they want to reopen the complex. They sincerely want to reopen of the complex through immediate normalization of inter-Korean relations,” said Kim with the Kaesong Industrial Complex Association. "When Kaesong was shut down in 2016, the conservative government of then President Park Geun-hye claimed 70% of the $100 million in wages paid each year, which was given directly to the government in Pyongyang to distribute to the workers, was diverted to finance the North’s illicit nuclear weapons program. However an official with the current pro-engagement administration of President Moon Jae-in has said there is no evidence that North Korea diverted Kaesong wages to its weapons programs.
~~~~~~~
COMMENT:  @amory 10.  It would be appreciated if GJ Admins would acknowledge that they were aware of what may be happening and why it does/doesn't satisfy this question. As events have unfolded, I have come to the conclusion that this situation is analogous to a gang breaking into a grocery store in its territory, taking over operation of the store, and declaring it open.  Such a scenario would not be considered a legal re-opening of the store; it would be considered an illegal looting even if the customers were paying for the merchandise.  Therefore while some factories may be operating, I'd say that Kaesong is not open. Does this situation bode well or ill for re-opening soon?  Clearly, SK businesses would like it to be re-opened, as, apparently, does the DPRK because of the foreign currency it gains through it, and the new SK government seems to be more pro-engagement.  So, I wouldn't be surprised if I started to read about negotiations to re-open it.  However, because of the increased sanctions and the possibility that DPRK is preparing to launch another missile, it may be politically very difficult to pull off.   And, thus far, the factory owners haven't even been able to inspect their property.   Another DPRK missile launch would kill it, I think.
At least the DPRK unilateral reopening will trigger negotiations to mutually reopen.

“If sanctions lead to a change in the North Korean nuclear program, our first priority will be tackling the issue of reopening the Kaesong Industrial Complex,” South Korean Unification Minister Cho Myoung-gyon said on Aug. 25. While Cho said this was contingent on progress on the North Korean nuclear and missile issues, the statement reconfirms the new administration’s strong commitment to reopening the Kaesong Complex.
Cho made the remarks during a forum about the new administration’s plans for North Korean policy that was held at the University of North Korean Studies in the Samcheong neighborhood of Seoul by the Unification Future Forum under Chairman Ryoo Kihl-jae on the morning of Aug. 25. “I find myself thinking that there may be no better way to change North Korea than the Kaesong Industrial Complex,” the minister said.

http://english.yonhapnews.co.kr/news/2017/08/23/0200000000AEN20170823003500315.html "South Korea is not considering reopening the joint industrial park in North Korea's Kaesong, at least for now, the presidential office Cheong Wa Dae said Wednesday . . . "We want to clarify the issue because it may send a wrong message not only to our people but also those in other countries,"

SEOUL, Aug. 23 (Yonhap) -- South Korea is not considering reopening the joint industrial park in North Korea's Kaesong, at least for now, the presidential office Cheong Wa Dae said Wednesday, dismissing news reports that suggested the possibility. "We want to clarify the issue because it may send a wrong message not only to our people but also those in other countries," a Cheong Wa Dae official told reporters. The reports followed a Monday meeting between South Korean President Moon Jae-in and a group of U.S. lawmakers, including Rep. Carolyn Maloney (D-NY). "In the meeting, President Moon had simply pointed out that introducing the North Korean people to market economy and changing the way they think was a very effective way to change the way North Korea behaves and that the Kaesong complex did contribute to such efforts," the official said, while speaking on condition of anonymity.

http://www.koreaherald.com/view.php?ud=20170801000838
South Korea's opposition parties on Tuesday ramped up their offensive against President Moon Jae-in's pursuit of dialogue and rapprochement with North Korea, as its recent long-range missile test has brought security to the center of political debate. The main opposition Liberty Korea Party, in particular, called for a wholesale review of Moon's policy toward the provocative neighbor, stressing its Friday test of an intercontinental ballistic missile is reshaping the security landscape on the peninsula and beyond. "The North's ICBM test is fundamentally changing the contours of security," Shim Jae-cheol, an LKP member and the National Assembly vice speaker, told Yonhap News Agency over the phone. "We have to thoroughly review our policy."
"At a time when the international community seeks to achieve the North's denuclearization through pressure and sanctions, the pursuit of dialogue with the North would be ineffective. ... We fear it could rather cause misjudgment on the part of the North," Park said in a radio interview. Concerns about "Korea passing" have also emerged as Trump held phone talks first with Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe over the North's latest missile test, with critics arguing that Seoul could be sidelined in security affairs involving the North. Capitalizing on public security concerns, the LKP redoubled its calls for the full-on deployment of the Terminal High Altitude Area Defense battery, a US missile defense system whose installation in the South has been suspended pending an environmental impact assessment. The ruling Democratic Party weighed in to defend the president, saying that the government would hold fast to its two-track approach of mixing dialogue and pressure, while it would sternly deal with the North's provocations. "Even during wartime, dialogue continues," Kim Tae-nyeon, the DP policy chief, said. "While building a robust defense system based on the South Korea-US alliance and applying sanctions and pressure, dialogue should also run in parallel." (Yonhap)
The current active missile programme and possible future nuclear tests, as well as DPRK's negative attitude towards the THAAD deployment, make this unlikely to happen any time soon.

N.Korea Snubs Old Partner Hyundai Group
Pyongyang has also snubbed other overtures from the new administration in Seoul and South Korean civic groups in recent weeks. Hyundai Asan has traditionally served as a bellwether and messenger in contacts with the North, but this time there is clearly no appetite for renewed exchanges. "Pyongyang is currently in hardline mode against Washington over the nuclear and missile issue and only interested in pressuring Seoul into suspending joint military drills with the U.S.," said Prof. Nam Sung-wook of Korea University.

Four very volatile leaders dictate the direction of this answer: Trump, Xi, Putin, and Kim.  If it was only Kim, I'd be in 100% on not before 1 August 2018.

Moon would like to do this but it may take a while for tensions to ease up. The opening of Kaesong could also be used as an opening for improved relations. Rex Tillerson's most recent statement that the US is not looking for regime change also gives an opening for improved relations.
The new SK president is a talker and pacifist.

The trend for Korean relations has been quite negative for years and while president Moon has tried to improve relations, I don't see an serious sign that North Korea is interested. Really all the evidence I see is that the north is more interested in its nuclear and missile programs than pursuing diplomatic improvements with the south. They haven't even formally replied to Moon's offer of talks, although I suppose silence weeks after the offer is about as official an answer as we need.

When I first read this question I thought, "What a stupid question!  No way!"  Then, "Well, on second thought, maybe it's not such a dumb question; there IS a new regime in SK .  . . hm" So, thinking in print, here's the reasons that come to my mind. Why it may re-open
-it is a source of hard currency for DPRK, which needs it desperately
-it has acted like a "bridge" between SK & DPRK
-the new regime in SK seems eager to do anything and everything it can to keep channels of communication and interaction open with DPRK Why it may not open
-It may be difficult to find interested businesses.  How many times can a business get yanked around and still be viable?  How many times has it been closed for political reasons almost overnight?  What would be the incentives for a business to be a part of it?  It was closed for 5 months in 2013, then open for about 30 months, then (now) closed since Feb 2016.  According to wikipedia, the 123 companies operating in Kaesong experienced losses equaling a combined £575 million ($944 million), during 5 months the last time it was closed.  What might the losses be this time, now that it has been closed for about 18 months? 
-international pressure may prevent it.  It seems to me that it would violate US & international sanctions. . . . U.S. economic sanctions against DPRK prohibit imports of key technologies and goods, such as computers
-Who wants it to re-open?  and how much do they want it?  DPRK labor now costs more than it did when the park was created because of DPRK demands, so there's less profit to be made. 
-Will its re-opening be linked to some sort of sanctions relief for DPRK or agreement for DPRK to cease missile or nuke tests or for SK to not accept THAAD?    If so--and why wouldn't it be?--that will complicate/delay the re-opening.
-talks would be complicated and difficult.   Bottomline for me at this point is that until talks begin, it looks like it will be a long time.
